SolForge is an online card game unlike any other. A great mix of familiar and unfamiliar mechanics that you may or may not know from other games.  In comparison with other games like Hearthstone, this game focuses more on gameknowledge and actual player skill and thus has not implemented more than a few elements of randomness, thus making skill, deck choice and knowledge much more valuable than luck". There are plenty of cards with crazy effects out there which makes the game so much more fun once you acquire some of them and put them into your deck or even build one around these cards. Thanks to in-game tournaments you can be able to play completely for free and get your hands on everything. Also there isn't anything in the shop that gives you any advantage whatsoever other than well having more cards. And while that definitely helps you grow your collection and be able to share cards with other players it is by no means necessary!

Another incredibly amazing thing about this game is that the developers give you 2 free boosterpacks every single day for logging in and winning 3 matches. If you are short on time that day you can play against the AI and it will still count! The developers did an amazing job in designing the game and its mechanics. It is free to play and easy to get into. The developers are also very generous in giving out plenty of codes to the community that provide you with ingame benefits such as

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While the central mechanics are interesting, they feel poorly put together. Each turn is basically a coin toss as to whether or not you will be able to do anything good. While strategic play can influence this to a point, the fact that you discard what's left of your hand and draw a brand new one each turn makes planning ahead difficult, not to mention that going several turns drawing level-1 cards which no longer have any impact once the stronger level-2 and level-3 cards appear is incredibly common and will often lead to losing any advantage you may have had, if not to losing the game outright.

Aside from the fact that luck is far too great an element in this game, the balancing is an issue as well. Having spend 150 hours of in-game time on this game, I managed to acquire a grand total of 3 legendary cards and there were plenty of heroic cards I hadn't even seen at that point. At this point, I feel like I should mention that not only are the interesting effects mostly limited to legendary and heroic cards and many (if not most) deck archetypes are completely based around them, but in the few cases where they can be compared to the less rare cards they are almost always better. Who'd rather have a nexus core than a thundersaur? Who could make a removal deck without dreadbolt, a lifegain deck without Oros/Arboris or a metamind deck without Drix? Why is Chrogias better than scrapforge titan, echowisp better than ether hounds, hinterland watchman better than cypien infiltrator, etc?

When we take the combination of poor balancing, slow releases, and the always overhanging element of luck and then add a UI that would've looked bad in 2005, the fact that card effects trigger in a random order, the fact that there is no reason to play more than 3 games a day, locking drafts to an average of 6 games (not 6 drafts, 6 GAMES) a week if you win half your games, the poor matchmaking and the frequently exploited fact that there are no turn timers - only a chess clock of 20 minutes, we get a game with interesting basic mechanics but unspeakably poor execution.

While the review says I don't recommend this game, I actually recommend that you play this ONCE if you're intersted in TCGs, because the mechanics at the base of SolForge are actually fairly interesting and might change some things you take for granted in a TCG. But I do not recommend playing more than that and I beg you not to spend money on this. SolForge might be worth returning to one day, but do not expect that day to come anytime soon.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SolForge is an interesting take on the digital card genre. It's a fairly simplistic card game, but with a suprising amount of depth / theorycrafting to your decks once you've unlocked some cards. It has the unique aspect of your cards levelling up as you play them; adding a depth of strategy that other card games haven't really explored. Not only do you have to think about what card to play right now, in order to damage your opponent, or save yourself from damage, but you also have to think about the future - and which cards you'll want then and how your deck will evolve compared to their deck.

The starter decks are playable, but I would strongly advise you to buy some packs (you can use silver which you can get from logging on daily and from winning matches) and get a custom deck going. You will get your ♥♥♥ kicked taking your cheap/free decks into PvP, but you can win your silver rewards playing against the AI - which is beatable on all difficulties with the starter decks, although the higher difficulties will be a challenge. If you do use real money to purchase packs, you will have a higher chance of getting the best cards, ultimately people should remember that card games are about spending money and RNG, but overall this is very playable as a free player too.

One of the big advantages of this game right now to me is that the Ipad app is extremely fluid and responsive. You can play untimed games with friends and the push notifications are accurate - meaning if you have a lazy day with 5 minutes to spare here and there, you can have a good duel with your friend from anywhere. (Untimed) games save despite the application being shut down; and you can start a game on the ipad and continue it on the PC, or have the game running in two locations at once if you so desire. A lot of digital card games right now have promised this sort of cross platform interactivity, but few have competently provided it yet. The android app is sadly not out yet so I can't comment on that - but they have said there'll be one in the future.

I'm pretty happy with it overall and would recommend.

This is a card game in transition, and stone blade entertainment is trying their best to move this product towards completion, but it's not there yet. So consider this a review of a very half-finished game.

The balance of the game is a work in progress" to say the least with some factions having some seemingly near impossible creatures to answer. Now, in April and having played Solforge for a few months, I think I can speak enough about the game to warrant a review. Solforge has four factions and hundreds of cards. Games are played with creatures and spells, the former being placed in any of the five lanes and the latter having various effects. Creatures in lanes will battle" opposing creatures in the same lane. If they are unopposed

Exciting, fresh and unique, SolForge is a must-have up-and-comer on the digital CCG scene, and being free-to-play, offers no excuse not to give it a chance.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Note before this begins: This is my very first Steam Review. Coupled with the fact I'm rather poor at giving feedback, I apologize in advance for this review's probably not being up to par with most peoples'. I'll be returning to this review to alter and add onto it, as I am oft wont to do; and just as well, as a read of what is below will demonstrate that in a single session, I cannot compose anything even remotely approaching the standards of an acceptably comprehensive body.

Disclaimer: This review is based wholly upon my own experience and opinion of the game. I do not claim to speak for anyone else, nor presume to, nor do I believe my opinion to be factual, nor any closer to objective truth than anyone else's. I entrust the reader to understand this applies to the whole of the review, including sentences wherein clauses that disclaim this are absent.

___

Like more than a few 90's kids, I definitely met the Battle Card Genre growing up. The Pokemon Trading Card Game; Yu-Gi-Oh; Digimon; and many more battle card games caught the interest of so many others in my age group (and beyond, even!). All of these were very popular, I took a look at all of them- and I never took to any of them. The Battle Card game genre was simply not for me, and still largely hasn't been.

Even so, there's been something interesting about the genre and many of its products in my opinion, even from a distance. So I've spent time of late looking for one that I might be able to enjoy. Countless ones, I've read of, seen numerous demonstrations for, and found myself uninterested in, just like old times.

Then, the two nights preceding the one wherein I write this review, I gave it another try. I found two very interesting prospective games. One, is Infinity Wars. It looks amazing, and I'd love to try it, but it commands space my potato cannot provide.

The other is SolForge.

Well, I installed it last night, started playing today, and if my impressions must be expressed in a single sentence, let it be this: I, someone who has never played a battle card game before, like, perhaps even am finding love for, this game.

I must start with the gameplay itself. As most reading this probably know, the game's playing area consists of ten spaces in a five-by-two arrangement. One strip of five is used by each of the two players; each space can be occupied by a card. In my opinion, this provides enough room for strategy to truly matter, while at the same time not intimidating a player as the presentation of a vast field can sometimes do. This having been said, a somewhat claustrophobic feeling often sets in when placing a card, adding a feeling of tension that can throw a player off-focus- which, in my opinion, is very satisfying to focus through the fog of.

Cards come in two variants: Creature and Spell. Creature cards have two statistics, Attack Power and Health, and most of them have a special ability (and/or multiple ones, in the case of some cards) There are four main factions, each with its own pool of cards. Once again, simplicity that provides room for complexity.

There are many other rules of the game that I'd love to individually praise, but I realize this is dragging on. I'll probably return to add onto the list and give my critique of each element of the gameplay that I can in kind on one of the aforementioned review edits I'm bound to do. Until then, let us move on.

The instilling of a feeling of tension mentioned in the paragraph about the playing field is just as well, as the cards in this game represent troops fighting and dying within the game's fictional universe. That brings me to what I'd like to talk about next: The appeal thereof.

In my opinion, the creators of this game have done a splendid job of making the lore and universe of this game very interesting. Each of the four main factions has its own unique characters, locations, and (most notably in my mind) culture and elements there-comprising, including their own unique ideals, established government, and general mindset toward life, the world, and even to each other. If you are interested, I'd advise to go to the developers' official website for the game and read their lore section. The descriptions there are highly descriptive, and will give you an idea of the world one is stepping into. There are no direct third-person descriptions of such nature in the game itself, ironically, nor any link to the official website- something I have mixed feelings about.

Even though direct explanations are not provided in the game itself, the game's universe does shine through- and how! In the campaign modes, the Info" bubbles often relay colorful descriptions of the setting in which your avatar (you?) find(s) her/him/yourself
date: and/or interactions with the culture of the given faction that one will be facing off against.\n\nAdditionally
recommended: and in my opinion most noticeably

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I play casually so if you're into competitive play, there might be some pay to win elements, but that's pretty much every collectible card game ever made so it's not out of the ordinary. You can buy cards with currency you earn by playing though.

Solforge is a fun free to play collectible card game. It plays a bit differently than your average card game like Magic the Gathering and Hearthstone. There is no resource system, each turn you can place up to two cards into lanes on the play field. Cards can only battle the cards directly across from them (not counting special abilities) in that lane, so you'll need to place them to counter your opponent's cards.  When you play a card, it levels up, and a higher level version of that card goes into your discard pile. Every four turns you shuffle your discard pile into your deck so you can play more powerful cards. They can level from rank one all the way up to three.

After you play your cards you can attack and if there is no card blocking your attacking cards you'll deal damage to the player. Your cards have a persistent health number, so weaker cards can eventually take down a more powerful one unless the player uses healing abilities or buffs. Some cards have the ability to switch lanes. There's a wide variety of card types, spells, and special abilities. There are pre-made decks or you can build your own.

The game is also available on iTunes and Google Play and your account is shared across platforms. So you'll have all of your cards whether you play on PC, Apple or Android devices. I tried playing it on my phone, but the cards were too hard to read so you'd have to play it on a tablet (unless you memorized what every card does).

The client needs some work. The cards and text are a little blurry when you play the game fullscreen so hopefully they'll be introducing higher resolution graphics later on, but it's still readable and works fine.

Once the game is out of Early Access I think it will be pretty great. It's free to play so it's worth trying out at least.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My review of Solforge used to be longer, and sort of confusing. That, and my impression of the game has changed quite a bit, so I decided to delete the old review.

The core mechanic of Solforge, card leveling, is incredibly unique, to the point that a lot of people won't grasp how it affects deckbuilding and gameplay for a very long time.

While SolForge seems like it doesn't have much strategy, it is actually incredibly deep, and every turn has very intricate decisions. You have to balance the desire to not fall behind on the board with leveling the cards that are going to help you win later. Using your life as a resource is imperitive when you are behind, and choices such as choosing the correct empty lane to put a creature into can be incredibly important. Tight play is rewarded very well in SolForge.

Deckbuilding is also incredibly deep. You see your entire deck every game, which allows for narrow but powerful cards to be included in decks. When building, you have to plan the entire arc you want to follow in game. Do you plan to play very aggressively with powerful level 2 cards, or do you fill your deck with insane level 3 creatures, and build the rest of the deck to buy you time to get them out?

The leveling mechanic makes drafting SolForge incredible. Every game I play with draft decks feels unique, since different cards get leveled, based on what my opponent was playing.

In short, in a lot of ways, SolForge is too clever for its own good. The game's design is super simple, but the leveling mechanic has a ripple effect on strategy. I have so much fun brewing decks every day.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solforge: A fine time waster for TCG fans.

The Good:
A decent amount of content available to a non-paying player
Unique gameplay system, not quite hearthstone, not quite MTG
Satisfies that TCG itch, for a while
Cross-play on Android :)

The Bad:
Gameplay gets stale after so long
Not much bang for your buck, if you are paying, you are paying a lot.
Campaign is a joke compared to what we backed on Kickstarter

Overall, I'd recommend this to TCG players looking for a little distraction
from the norm.  I wouldnt consider this a full fledged competitive TCG as
most people online just have better cards that do better things and encourage
you to spend lots of money trying to get the cards you need.

F2P - 4/5
P2P - 2/5

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Note before this begins: This is my very first Steam Review. Coupled with the fact I'm rather poor at giving feedback, I apologize in advance for this review's probably not being up to par with most peoples'. I'll be returning to this review to alter and add onto it, as I am oft wont to do; and just as well, as a read of what is below will demonstrate that in a single session, I cannot compose anything even remotely approaching the standards of an acceptably comprehensive body.

Disclaimer: This review is based wholly upon my own experience and opinion of the game. I do not claim to speak for anyone else, nor presume to, nor do I believe my opinion to be factual, nor any closer to objective truth than anyone else's. I entrust the reader to understand this applies to the whole of the review, including sentences wherein clauses that disclaim this are absent.

___

Like more than a few 90's kids, I definitely met the Battle Card Genre growing up. The Pokemon Trading Card Game; Yu-Gi-Oh; Digimon; and many more battle card games caught the interest of so many others in my age group (and beyond, even!). All of these were very popular, I took a look at all of them- and I never took to any of them. The Battle Card game genre was simply not for me, and still largely hasn't been.

Even so, there's been something interesting about the genre and many of its products in my opinion, even from a distance. So I've spent time of late looking for one that I might be able to enjoy. Countless ones, I've read of, seen numerous demonstrations for, and found myself uninterested in, just like old times.

Then, the two nights preceding the one wherein I write this review, I gave it another try. I found two very interesting prospective games. One, is Infinity Wars. It looks amazing, and I'd love to try it, but it commands space my potato cannot provide.

The other is SolForge.

Well, I installed it last night, started playing today, and if my impressions must be expressed in a single sentence, let it be this: I, someone who has never played a battle card game before, like, perhaps even am finding love for, this game.

I must start with the gameplay itself. As most reading this probably know, the game's playing area consists of ten spaces in a five-by-two arrangement. One strip of five is used by each of the two players; each space can be occupied by a card. In my opinion, this provides enough room for strategy to truly matter, while at the same time not intimidating a player as the presentation of a vast field can sometimes do. This having been said, a somewhat claustrophobic feeling often sets in when placing a card, adding a feeling of tension that can throw a player off-focus- which, in my opinion, is very satisfying to focus through the fog of.

Cards come in two variants: Creature and Spell. Creature cards have two statistics, Attack Power and Health, and most of them have a special ability (and/or multiple ones, in the case of some cards) There are four main factions, each with its own pool of cards. Once again, simplicity that provides room for complexity.

There are many other rules of the game that I'd love to individually praise, but I realize this is dragging on. I'll probably return to add onto the list and give my critique of each element of the gameplay that I can in kind on one of the aforementioned review edits I'm bound to do. Until then, let us move on.

The instilling of a feeling of tension mentioned in the paragraph about the playing field is just as well, as the cards in this game represent troops fighting and dying within the game's fictional universe. That brings me to what I'd like to talk about next: The appeal thereof.

In my opinion, the creators of this game have done a splendid job of making the lore and universe of this game very interesting. Each of the four main factions has its own unique characters, locations, and (most notably in my mind) culture and elements there-comprising, including their own unique ideals, established government, and general mindset toward life, the world, and even to each other. If you are interested, I'd advise to go to the developers' official website for the game and read their lore section. The descriptions there are highly descriptive, and will give you an idea of the world one is stepping into. There are no direct third-person descriptions of such nature in the game itself, ironically, nor any link to the official website- something I have mixed feelings about.

Even though direct explanations are not provided in the game itself, the game's universe does shine through- and how! In the campaign modes, the Info" bubbles often relay colorful descriptions of the setting in which your avatar (you?) find(s) her/him/yourself
date: and/or interactions with the culture of the given faction that one will be facing off against.\n\nAdditionally

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The developers of this game are simply awful. Some of the worst around. SolForge was released on Steam in March of 2013 as an Early Access title and its current development status is still very close to what it was back then. There is usually only one update per year. Sometimes two updates per year if we're lucky and those updates change very little about the game client and user interface. The developers care more about releasing new cards than patching and fixing the game client and user interface, which is currently the equivalent of a phone game from about the year 2006. Due to the developers' decisions and unbelievably slow progress, the player-base has been getting smaller and smaller. The death of this game is near and the developers have practically abandoned any prospect of a positive future as the updates come rarely and slowly. I haven't actually played a SolForge match in over two years. The only reason why I still have it installed and why I still load it every day is because I stupidly and regretfully spent money on it. Every day I load the game only to get the daily rewards. At least that way I don't feel as bad for wasting money on this worthless piece of software and on awful developers.

Don't be like me. Don't waste your time and money on a product that has been developed like garbage by despicable developers who couldn't care less.

SolForge is a disaster.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

SolForge is another entry into the recently-full group of Collectible Card Games, but it takes a fresh and unique approach to the otherwise-tired genre. Gone are the typical Magic:the Gathering clone features -- it removes the single card draw at the start of the turn, the 60 card deck slot, and even the concept of a graveyard. Instead, you get an incredibly deep, strategic system that demands you plan ahead, but flexibly (since RNG is still going to determine which cards you see).

The most interesting part of the game is also its core: the cards you play level up each time you play them, to a maximum of level 3. Each time you level a card, it gets more powerful, sometimes exponentially so. But what makes this more strategic is that every 4 turns you reshuffle your played or discarded cards back into your deck. Since you draw 5 cards a turn, you're seeing 2/3 of your 30-card deck every 4 turns. It adds an insane level of consistency to your draws, if you plan accordingly.

All in all, it's a game that's got a lot more depth than your typical CCG, and it is entirely Free-to-Play if you're willing to take a beating at first. (It takes about a month to really build the card pool based on the current daily rewards, but they're working to improve that too.) Definitely worth looking into!

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun free to play game.

Excellent tutorial, easy to get into. After a few hours I was playing on hard against the computer, which is just right for me (I lose, I win, I groan at missing the obvious move after ending my turn, I am happy when I manage to turn the table from a bad start,...).

Gameplay: You play creature or spell cards against an opponent, taking turns. Creatures have attack and health, and some have nifty special abilities. That and the spells is what makes this so fun and always different every game. Do you play a spell that gives one of your own creatures +3 attack, stolen from a creature the opponent has, or do you play a creature that can hit anyone with its attack on the next turn? Playing a card also means it's better next time you are dealt it (each has 3 levels), look to the future! You only get 5 cards to pick from every turn (exceptions may come with new, non-starter deck cards).

The game is also very nice at asking you to confirm stuff that isn't really good for you.

You start with 2 decks of 30 cards each, of which you can use either, or a combination you make yourself from the cards in them. To start with the opponent is the computer on easy, normal, or hard, whose decks you can also decide.

I eventually caved in and signed up on their site for the rewards you can get. (For logging in, winning 1 game, and winning 3 games, once every 24h.) And I already got some nifty new cards to use and in-game currency to buy moar cards, all for free!

This also enables me to make my own decks, with said nifty new cards! Only restriction is that you can combine only 2 of the 4 different groups of cards (kinda robots, elements, undead, and nature) per deck. But you can make more than the obvious 6 different combos, with all the cards you soon pile up!

There is the option to use real money, but from what I can see and read in discussions, everything can be had without that.

And  I'd like to play with friends (you need to sign up too, for that). I'm too much of  a coward to play with random strangers yet (also an option when you're logged in).

Plus there's tournaments for folks who are into that!

Here's some screenshots.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=206932525
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=211887233

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The Good: Solid card game with a good balance between strategy and fun. Many possible deck variations choosing from 4 different card pools. Nice short games (usually). Very generous with booster pack unlocks and in-game currency. Syncs with mobile versions of the game. Nice level-up mechanic that introduces addition strategy into the very act of playing the cards. Simple, easy to read interface. Great artwork and some of the cards have a neat evolution of appearance as the cards level up. Recent updates slowly add a new expansion set of cards.

The Bad: A bit simple if you're a veteran of Magic: the Gathering. Hard to see what the opponent plays sometimes because it flashes by too quickly (although you can go back to the log to look). Only 4 schools/houses of spells. Not as well polished as Hearthstone which has nice spell animations and creature sounds and highlights spells and effects as they happen. Deck construction is a little messy the way the cards are displayed although the filters do help. Slightly clunky menus and interface in general.

Overall: Great card game that is worth spending your time in. Great on the go, especially if you link the game to a mobile device. Simpler than Magic but still fun. Lacks the polish and oomph of Hearthstone's sound and animation but far more generous with free card/booster unlocks and in-game currency. That's honestly the main thing that really keeps me hooked to logging in daily. Otherwise, I'd probaly spend more time grinding Blizzard's game which requires a lot more grinding to unlock cards unless you want to spend cash. Ultimately, I am divided between both online CCGs and find them both equally enjoyable in different ways.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I signed up for the Early Access for Sol Forge but ended up being unable to play it on my PC unfortunately because it runs into a DEP windows error which I have been unable to solve and the DEVs said they would look in to it but never got back to me. I can only assume it isn't common enough to be worth their time to figure out what it is. After trying a bunch of different things on my own I gave up in mid  August which is when they went gold with it.

Full disclosure: I do have the game installed on my laptop too and that works fine but I rarely use my Laptop at home (where I have a guaranteed internet connection) and when I do go out with it I usually have other things I need doing instead. Sol Forge seems like a fairly basic game but I can't really say whether I like it or not since I've never played a person with it, only the bots which are predictably bad.

My no" is with the caveat that is you like simpler CCGs and don't want to really think too much during play then Sol Forge might fit your bill. But Caveat Emptor. There are no refunds (if you buy packs and then find it suddenly doesn't work for some reason) and no one will care if it doesn't work for you.

My initial reason for getting Early Access had less to do with what I knew about the game (not a lot) and more to do with who was making it. Brian Kibler
date: Justin Gary and crew have been involved with CCGs for a very long time indeed and have some amazing credentials between them. I've never gotten a chance to play their other big game Ascension but as I understand it
recommended: it is quite elegant and powerfully fun. Sadly Sol Forge didn't strike me that way though it has its charms.\n\nThe 5 factions are I assume just the beginning of the diversity as I am sure many sets will be produced eventually. I hope someday I have something more positive to say about the game."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The closest game I can equate SolForge to is chess.  Chess with cards, which means the chess pieces are not always the same, nor does your opponent have the same pieces as you posess.

So, why do I equate it with chess. I equate it with chess as it is the only game, I came over to Steam from playing SolForge on my iPhone, I have played on my phone that allows me to think. To really use my brain. The process of using my losses and wins, by utilizing the knowledge and wisdom of other players on the various forums, and building on experience I gain by playing everyday. Rewards me with a  deep satisfaction, and a sense of enhancing my brain as I received over the years of learning and playing chess.

I do not know how to recommend to someone well or  high enough to play SolForge. Nor how to thank all those involved in creating and continually improving this wonderful game. Particularly in comparision to the benefits I receive  by playing this game not to mention my  appreciation to all involved with SolForge for their generosity in the countless gifts the give to help their players, which to me is so very kind of them, and when combined with the benefits I stated earlier makes this game, to me, an absolute joy and a priceless gem.

Sincerely,

Strangebear

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A very elegant set of core rules gone to waste because the developers refuse to design their card sets in a manner that actually fits the game. Anyone who understands CCGs will notice eventualy that there is excessive variance and how the late stages of a match are a prolonged coin toss.

There is content locked for non-paying players, and grinding for in game product is out of the question because in-game currency has little value. No room for casual players.

Solforge is one tragedy of a virtual CCG. It will trap you for a couple of months until the novelty of its leveling system and draw engine cool off, but in its current form it deserves neither your time nor money.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fairly typical free to play CCG, this game doesn't really do anything special to separate it from the pack. The UI isn't as nice as it could be, and frankly it feels worse than Hearthstone overall. And, like all F2P CCGs on the computer, it is vastly inferior to Magic: The Gathering.

Why can't any of these games be as good as Magic? Who knows.

This game's central mechanic is the idea of levelling cards during a match - by playing a card, you get a better version of the card shuffled into your deck in the future. This means that over the course of the game, your cards (and your opponent's cards) get progressively stronger. This leads to, in principle, an interesting tension of now vs later, but the reality is that the best cards are simply good now and even better later, and while there are some trade-offs, and there is some strategy involved, in the end it isn't really all that amazing.

It was a valiant effort, but frankly, you're better off playing a real game.

I also would like to point out this is a collectable card game. Just like all collectable card games it involves investment. dont look at the F2P like oh i can win! It does take time. Thats why i say if u like card games and understad what collectable card game are, enjoy!  it is top notch.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Wanna know how much worth it it is, compared to MTG? BIG TIME. Mostly because it does what MTG doesn't:

1. The gameplay is more simplified.
2. There ARE no infinite combos; that's because the game is STRICTLY strategy based, where you can only use two cards per turn!
3. It's FREE TO PLAY! And no terrible freemium offers, either!
4. You can earn cards and booster packs, by simply PLAYING the game!

If you like MTG, you might like this, better; it's simple, once you get the hang of it...plus, you don't have to pay, just to play campaign missions! This is a MUST, for anyone who wants a simplified alternative, to MTG.

(P.S.; to those who don't know what MTG" stands for

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solforge is one of the more unique online collectable card games. A feature which really sets it aside, is that once a card is cast, it levels to the next tier, adding new abilities and stronger stats the next time it is drawn. It still has a large amount of depth for something that seems quite streamlined at first.The gameplay is somewhat simpler than more in depth games such as magic the gathering, and luck can have somewhat more of an influence on occasion. This can lead to some epic comebacks and to some fights where you just didn't quite get what you needed. Most of the time, fortunately, your own card decisions and anticipations of the other players moves and deck composition are still strong enough determining factors for victory ( although not all would agree). This is assuming the other player has a similar skill level and deck level to your own,which is not guaranteed with every match just yet, hopefully a ranking system will be fully implemented.

Is it fun and worth grinding through and throwing a few quid at ( I've spent £3.50) ? It was for me, try it and make a decision. I wouldnt recommend spending much more than 5-10 quid ot get you going, if anything. You can grind through and learn, learning from other players in the community and your wins/losses.

The game has a really quality feature of weekly tournaments, which you can enter with event tickets ( fairly easy to obtain for free). There are constructed tournaments ( pre made decks - stay away until you have some stronger decks made) and draft competitions, where you make a deck from the cards given out. In the non-casual draft, you can actually keep all the cards you pick  in addition to some you win. I can't stress enough the importance of this! you get to keep some horoic and rare cards that are essential to the cores of certain deck builds. It will dramatically increase your card and deck arsenal whilst you enjoy some more evenly matched draft based games. You will have some poor draft tounaments some times, picking the wrong card combos. It's not always ideal, but its quite consistent with choices offered.

Yes, some players who are silly enough or rich enough do pay for cards and get there quicker (although high pricing of this approach seems to discourage it, imo). But this is the case with many free to play games. The important thing is you can get there spending next to nothing in my opinion anyway, and I personally found the journey to be a fulfilling one, full of ups and downs.

You can also play on your phone or tablet, although lag can be an issue.

If hearthstone didn't grip you, Solforge might. If you loved hearthstone, I'm sure you will enjoy solforge as well.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've only just started playing, and while my TCG exposure has only been a few matches of Magic, and 10 hours of Hearthstone, I have to say that this is a super fun one. The card art is great for the most part. Each creature card has 3 levels, and the card art changes as the card gets stronger mid game. A really unique mechanic and it's fun to have the game evolve to a stronger and stronger level as time goes on.

There's no mana in the game, so you can play any two cards in your hand during you turn, with the hand being entirely rerolled each turning, giving weight to the decision of which cards to play. This is because each time you play a card, you level it up, so the next time you draw the card, it'll be one level higher, often unlocking new abilities.

The game's not flawless though, there's not nearly the same amount of polish as a game like Hearthstone, and there's no visible ranking, although the game has a hidden ELO system, and there's a new UI incoming.

There's a great card selection, easily over 400 cards, if my math is right. A bunch of different types of spells and creatures, although there is some overlap between them. The best part about the game is that it basically throws currency at you, so you're able to buy a ♥♥♥♥ ton of basic cards. You get about 2000 to log in each day, and the most common of the cards can be bought for 150. I respect that, and I'm alright with there being rarer cards worth up to 34k. The game's free to play, they need to make money somehow.

Overall, I heartily recommend the game.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I haven't spent a single cent on this game but I find myself playing it more than any other game on Steam or my android.  The great thing about Solforge is that all you have to do is login once a day and/or win a game and you get free cards and Silver.  The Silver you win can even be used to purchase additional booster packs with more cards!  After a week or two of playing the computer, I had a decent enough collection to build my own decks and play against others online.

If you download the android version, it syncs with your PC account so you can take your collection with you to the toilet.

The game isn't perfect.  I think the interface could be improved especially in deck building mode.  This is more of an issue with the mobile version of Solforge as opposed to the PC version.  There are still some balance issues to work out with individual cards but that's what patches are for.  Some players will let the timer run out on their turn if they are losing and force you to sit there for 10 minutes because they refuse to concede.  This is more of an issue with the community rather than the game but it's the only time I have ever been frustrated with Solforge.

If you are a fan of Magic: The Gathering or Adventure Time's Card Wars, you will enjoy Solforge.  It's easy to learn but difficult to master.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

7/10 *edited May 2015*

This game is a really good alternative to some of the broken Magic: duel of champions or duel of planeswalker games. Not saying they're all broken, but since they're ubisoft products, they usually are.

Similar to hearthstone, better in some ways (card selection), worse in others (pvp match timers)

Good:
- AI can provide a decent challenge on hard mode (when you first start out) since you can let it randomly use some of your best decks (or not).
-It's NOT P2W, no matter what anyone says. If they need to p2w then they're doing something seriously wrong. I do quite well for myself and have built a competitive number of decks just by doing dailies and competing in tournaments.  The game gives you quite a large number of good cards without having to buy extras - especially with the new campaign rewards.
- There's good balance amongst the factions
- lots of different ways to build your decks, you can combine 2 factions, or just go with 1, using as much or as little mixing as you want
- the cards themselves are well thought out and balanced, and the artwork is nice
- it's a nicely paced game, if you enjoy taking your time while you drink coffee or eat
- you can play multiple games at once, so you can play against the AI and a few opponents at once if that's your style
- lots of features and well thought out, simple, UI

Bad:
- the timed pvp matches are WAY too long. It's a good amount of time if you're not in a hurry or playing multiple opponents, but often an opponent will go AFK on you for most or all of the match, leaving you to forfeit or wait till the 20 minute timer is up. Each turn should be timed IMO, instead of the entire match being timed.
- Servers seem really unstable lately (May 2015), physical infrastructure support is needed.
- Client is really sluggish, too much loading, time between loading, and glitches


- Not sure what the Early Access" thing is about

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Really great F2P TCG! Very casual player here and I generally just play against bots (dailies) or do tournaments.

Recently a campaign mode was added, which was easy up until the last mission... very tough, for me at least. Zimus the Undying was a life-saver there! (gets killed, respawns... infinite loop, AI isn't smart enough to stop it)

Can get 1 or 2 booster packs per day and generally the prices aren't crazy in the shop. (sales and such) Lots of grinding if you intend to buy a single Legendary card, though.

Balancing is also very iffy here... some cards are totally OP, others are useless copies. Needs some tweaking for sure.

EDIT: My hours aren't totally correct; I play this game on my iPad. Probably have 15 hours logged on there.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

By today's standards SolForge is not a good game.  You can not directly choose which of your characters attacks the enemy characters nor can you directly choose which of your characters blocks the enemy characters.  You just lay out your creatures and hit the 'battle' button.  Very old-school mechanic which have been repeated by games like Battlegrounds with almost no success.

My review is based on about an hour of gameplay so that must be considered.  However, I don't see much value in this game when other free-to-play games are much better.  Games like Hearthstone, Infinity Wars, and Might and Magic: Duel of Champions make SolForge feel like a college project instead of a full-fledged game.

I liked the use of sound effects and graphics during combat...it's about the only appealing thing I found in this game.

4/10 - I'll come back in a year and check it out again

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have played this game for more than a year, and there are some good things in it. The changes make it better and better every time, but still it has so many bad things, that I've just stopped. There's no chat ingame, no way of trading cards and the most annoying is that you cannot change the settings for the animations, which made it freeze for me EVERY DAY I've played it. Also there are some bugs in it, like you can't have the same avatar all the time, sometimes the cards doesn't work (for example once Weirwood Patriarch gave it's bonus to lvl 1  Spirng Dryad which had no extra +1/+1 when entering the field, other times not), and there are days when the computer literally works against the player. I've seen people making combos which have chances to be possible below 0%, like drawing 2 Legendary cards in simple draft, or putting down two creatures and getting them back lvl 2 on the next round, or getting Solstice Reveler IN EVERY TURN when it worked but always upgraded. And as usual, it's impossible to defeat the rich kids, who have 3 Oros and 3 Varna's Pact in one deck...

As a cardgame it's inventive and enjoyable, but the little bad things make it a suffering on long terms.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It can feel a bit like a grind. I look at it as a great way to isolate and decompress my day for 15-20 minutes at a time. The game is pretty rewarding with its daily challenges. If you start off expecting to have under-powered decks (as you would in MTG) without spending money and stick to just getting the dailys done as best you can you will be happy with the result. After doing drafts once or twice you will see the cycle that works for players in the solforge f2p ccommunity.

This game offers both strategic, indepth thoughtful plays with fully-sculpted decks and it also offers very casual games amongst friends. Playing with a single buddy is a great way to start off for getting rewards and improving your own play.

A buddy of mine introduced me to it and I can say after 2-3 weeks of playing that I'm satisfied with what the game is. If you look at it as an actual indulgence and spend money, you find yourself playing amongst other tacticions who bring overwheling deck strategies and scary combos. And that makes YOU want to build those, unleashing horror on poor first-timer nooblets.

6/10. (Not enough boobies.)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This is a really fun card game.  If you like card games, you will probably like it a lot.  If you don't, you might still like it because it has a very unique and intuitive ruleset.  I love the card transformation mechanic, I like that decks are consistent (discards are shuffled back into the deck).  I like the five lanes and the way creature battles work--it simulates a battle on multiple fronts--though I think I would like it if you could choose on your turn for your creature not to attack (you could make it a defender, but that's a permanent solution to a temporary problem).  Because of all of these mechanics, this is also a good example of a card game that wouldn't work at all in physical form--it would be a pain in the ♥♥♥ to do all of that by hand.

The deck builder is rather well done, though I wish I could rescale the card size so I could view more of them at once (you can do it in text only, but I like to see the card).  The number of cards of that type you own is also right over the flavor text, which is annoying.  Deck building mechanics are similarly simple, yet interesting; there are four schools/kingdoms/worlds/colors/whatever and you can have no more than two in your deck.  You must have 30 cards in your deck.  Easy.  I normally don't like deck building--I'm a draft/arena kind of guy, from my M:tG days to the present with Hearthstone, but this game makes it simple enough to be fun.

The AI is also really good. I like to play against the computer primarily because I mostly just build decks and test them.  Hard computer is formidible enough to be interesting. If I've built a solid deck, I can beat them almost every time, even if they're using the same deck.  It is tuned to be a rather good gauge, I think.

TL;DR: It's free, it's easy to learn, there are a lot of interesting mechanics and interplay between them, and it's fun as hell.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The mechanics of the game seem interesting, and it has some neat strategies. You only really get free points to buy additional cards with from the dailies (login, first win, and third win) with minimal point gains on pvp wins beyond your first. There are also tournaments that you can enter using tickets that you obtain from pvp wins that can get you some cards even if you lose horribly.

Also as much as you can build a strategic deck and increase your chances of winning, this game is still very luck based and I have lost many many games purely because I get nothing useful in my hand (even with some of the prebuilt decks the game provides). This also applies to draft tournaments (where you build a deck off random cards the game gives you), where I have have had times where I was given only low tier cards, only to find my opponents having legendaries and many heroics (common -> rare -> heroic -> legendary) in their decks.

This game is early access though, so I hope they fix up some of these annoying mechanics and add ways to make your deck at least a little more reliable. I'll recommend it for now as it is free, and you can always get a head start on your card collection for when its polished up and released.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Fun game, a bit of a pay to win so buyer beware that I firmly believe you CANNOT succeed or even have realistic 'fun' unless you throw 30 ish dollars at the game (I recommend one of the steam packages, they really are the best deal available!)

That being said, if you are willing to throw a couple of bucks in, the game is a good quality TCG, balance is a work in progress but not overwhelmingly bad, community is pretty nice so far, drafts and freebies are decent, but you need a decent deck to viably get some of the daily free rewards.

All in all, If you have some dispensible income, love TCGs, and want some fun deck building, pack opening, and outwitting gameplay - give it a shot!

If you don't want to pay anything, you can still get the legendary rarity cards which are OP and very much required to be successful in most cases - over a matter of several months. So be aware the 'free' path is so excruciatingly slow it truly is not worth it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

A Review after a year in Solforge(from someone who's not a prior TCG player)
Summary right at the bottom.

After having played SOlforge for over a year now(having started during early access in August last year), I would to say a few things(good and bad) and hopefully new players can decide if the game is for them and whether they would want to spend more money and contribute to the development.

For those who are not familiar with this genre of games, Digital card games(DCGs) or Trading Card games(TCGs) probably first gained prominence through Magic:The Gathering some 20 years ago. Most have a system where there are multiple colours/factions/races and there are some differing mechanics to how you can construct a deck.

Ok, onto the game itself. The first thing will strke you about this game is the ease of learning it. I remember learning the mechanics in maybe 15minutes after playing the tutorials and a game or two - something not even remotely possible for more complex games like M:TG. This is actually good for players new to the genre, so as not to build fustration before getting into the game. Play on a bit more and you will also learn that learning is not mastering, and to beat other human players(and the hard AI as well), you will likely need to build a decent deck -- which brings me to the concept of deck building and building the collection of cards(because you obviously can't build a deck without cards).

Deck building in Solforge is super simple, with less things to ponder about like lands and the other myriad of card types in other card games. In Solforge, there are only two card types -creatures and spells- and no consideration of off turn acitivity like counterspells and such. Your deck can comprise of up to 2 factions(there are 4), and must have a minimum of 30 cards. That's pretty much it, but as I said if you are new to the genre, you will probably need some time to build a good deck. Along the way, you will realise losing is part of the process of deck-building-- what works in theory may often not pan out in actual games.

I will imagine new players having a little trouble getting some decks up in the first month or two while they build up their card collection. I started with 20 blue packs(some early puchase deal of sorts) as well as having the early access benefit of having access to all cards to experiment(just to play, not own them). However, the one BIG plus about the game is the speed of earning rewards. In solforge, there are 3 daily rewards(login, 1win and 3 win reward) and 1 for winning an online game. You may get boosters or individual cards, and will always earn silver, which may be used to buy any card which you already own. This system is especially useful if you dont wan't to blow like $10?(not sure how much exactly) on a single legendary which you may need more copies of to play around with.I recommend new players to play the easy/normal AI for a week or 2 to earn some rewards and build a deck before playing the hard AI or humans.Overall, having recently tested a couple of other games, I will say the rewards system in SF is pretty generous.

The gameplay mechanic revolves around the ranking up" system of cards where often cards that are weaker early on are more powerful at rank 2 or 3. There may be a few exceptions to this balance
date: but these are almost always legendary cards. Actual turns consist of 2 actions - either a spell
recommended: or a creature played down to one of the 5 lanes. Creatures in a lane fight against the opposing creature in the same lane every turn
hoursPlayed: so no tapping or assigning blockers needed. Despite the relative simplicity of the game I feel like it remains relevant and fun.I came from being in the chess club back in school and my only gripe is the RNG factor of drawing the big rank 3 cards during the first turn of rank 3

Early Access Review

Best casual card game I've played. (I've played hearthstone and a bunch of others.)

The thing that I love most about this is you don't need to play against random players to actually get cards and feel like you're progressing. I've played my entire time with my girlfriend and I still get the same rewards as anyone else who plays with randoms. We've both gotten plenty of legendaries too. It's not at all necessary to buy cards. It got updated recently to add 100 + cards or something too which is really nice.

The game itself is also pretty simple and there is an RNG factor of course (like all card games) but it really does depend on how you play and set up your deck. If you just wanna play a card game with your friends and not stinky randoms, this game is perfect.

I've never understood why games like hearthstone demand you play against randoms to actually get cards. especially when you can just buy them anyway. ANYWAY OK THANKS BYE ILU.

Game is a good free card thing. A bit cheap looking at times. Card Art is always nice though.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ORIGINALLY NOT EARLY ACCESS, SolForge is a decent free to play card game with some of the easiest mechanics of any card game I've ever played. Choose cards from four factions (nature, fire, death, and robots), make a 30 card deck, and fight the computer or an online opponent. You get two actions per turn (except for the first turn, when the player can only play one card), and as you play you gain levels in order to play higher-level cards. Any cards you don't play don't gain levels, and any cards you don't use get discarded.

Several cards synergize for higher levels of strategy, but overall this is a simple game anyone can play. If you don't mind being limited to only two actions per turn, that is.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros
- Very strategic at times (wide decision trees for those who like to mull it over)
- Very intuitive at times (narrowing those decision trees, on the surface, can seem quick and easy)
- Brewing (executing that master plan with your quirky combos is excellent)
- Drafting (picking and pairing happens asynchronously, no advantage for whales)
- Free currency (daily rewards in order to collect currency and cards are not tedious or overbearing)

Cons
- Interface for all devices is slow (you will think sometimes that you are disconnected from the world, but you're not)
- Interface for all devices is bugged (which means learning how to play the game well involves a period of trial and error regarding some game input/output, e.g., time clocks, cancelling card effects)
- Some card rules and interactions are not made clear (and after researching this a bit, it appears to be more of an issue of lazy programming than it is an issue of making the game newbie-friendly)
- Features which have been promised for a while (single-player campaign) have been put on the backburner in favor of some which weren't ever really needed

This game is always changing, but this list of pros and cons has remained the same since I started playing the first Steam-released version.

Summary right at the bottom.

After having played SOlforge for over a year now(having started during early access in August last year), I would to say a few things(good and bad) and hopefully new players can decide if the game is for them and whether they would want to spend more money and contribute to the development.

For those who are not familiar with this genre of games, Digital card games(DCGs) or Trading Card games(TCGs) probably first gained prominence through Magic:The Gathering some 20 years ago. Most have a system where there are multiple colours/factions/races and there are some differing mechanics to how you can construct a deck.

Ok, onto the game itself. The first thing will strke you about this game is the ease of learning it. I remember learning the mechanics in maybe 15minutes after playing the tutorials and a game or two - something not even remotely possible for more complex games like M:TG. This is actually good for players new to the genre, so as not to build fustration before getting into the game. Play on a bit more and you will also learn that learning is not mastering, and to beat other human players(and the hard AI as well), you will likely need to build a decent deck -- which brings me to the concept of deck building and building the collection of cards(because you obviously can't build a deck without cards).

Deck building in Solforge is super simple, with less things to ponder about like lands and the other myriad of card types in other card games. In Solforge, there are only two card types -creatures and spells- and no consideration of off turn acitivity like counterspells and such. Your deck can comprise of up to 2 factions(there are 4), and must have a minimum of 30 cards. That's pretty much it, but as I said if you are new to the genre, you will probably need some time to build a good deck. Along the way, you will realise losing is part of the process of deck-building-- what works in theory may often not pan out in actual games.

I will imagine new players having a little trouble getting some decks up in the first month or two while they build up their card collection. I started with 20 blue packs(some early puchase deal of sorts) as well as having the early access benefit of having access to all cards to experiment(just to play, not own them). However, the one BIG plus about the game is the speed of earning rewards. In solforge, there are 3 daily rewards(login, 1win and 3 win reward) and 1 for winning an online game. You may get boosters or individual cards, and will always earn silver, which may be used to buy any card which you already own. This system is especially useful if you dont wan't to blow like $10?(not sure how much exactly) on a single legendary which you may need more copies of to play around with.I recommend new players to play the easy/normal AI for a week or 2 to earn some rewards and build a deck before playing the hard AI or humans.Overall, having recently tested a couple of other games, I will say the rewards system in SF is pretty generous.

The gameplay mechanic revolves around the ranking up" system of cards where often cards that are weaker early on are more powerful at rank 2 or 3. There may be a few exceptions to this balance
date: but these are almost always legendary cards. Actual turns consist of 2 actions - either a spell
recommended: or a creature played down to one of the 5 lanes. Creatures in a lane fight against the opposing creature in the same lane every turn
hoursPlayed: so no tapping or assigning blockers needed. Despite the relative simplicity of the game I feel like it remains relevant and fun.I came from being in the chess club back in school and my only gripe is the RNG factor of drawing the big rank 3 cards during the first turn of rank 3

Early Access Review

Best casual card game I've played. (I've played hearthstone and a bunch of others.)

The thing that I love most about this is you don't need to play against random players to actually get cards and feel like you're progressing. I've played my entire time with my girlfriend and I still get the same rewards as anyone else who plays with randoms. We've both gotten plenty of legendaries too. It's not at all necessary to buy cards. It got updated recently to add 100 + cards or something too which is really nice.

The game itself is also pretty simple and there is an RNG factor of course (like all card games) but it really does depend on how you play and set up your deck. If you just wanna play a card game with your friends and not stinky randoms, this game is perfect.

I've never understood why games like hearthstone demand you play against randoms to actually get cards. especially when you can just buy them anyway. ANYWAY OK THANKS BYE ILU.

Game is a good free card thing. A bit cheap looking at times. Card Art is always nice though.

Early Access Review

awesome collectible card game

PRO:

* it's free
* crossplay on your mobile devices (tablets/smartphones)
* allows you to complete your daily quests against the A.I.
* generous quest rewards (you can get 2 packs/day and some coins by playing a few quick A.I. matches)
* great card art
* the 4 factions/colors feel very distinct
* fantastic CCG mechanics (imagine Hearthstone with lanes and Pokemon-style evolutions)
* easy to pick up, hard to master
* the game receives regular updates
* campaign mode is fun & free

CON:

* the interface looks/feels better on mobile devices
* online competition can be pretty hardcore for new players
* the A.I. is easily exploitable (just like in Hearthstone)

--> if you like CCG's you need to play this game

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Ok I am changing my review today.  The game is not at the level of smart one would have hoped for it to be.  Really, with the game as it stands, it is a troll game once you start to get good cards.  The only skil it seems to foster is in draft games: you need to be a good shopper and pick the best produce to fit in in your basket - then pretty much let the game run itself on auto pilot when you play.  Very rarely do you get to use your brain in this game, because:

1) card shuffle randomness
2) there is no deck for every situation
3) does your battle of the bulge beat your opponents blitz?
4) rarely does using multiple spells combat simply very strong creature cards- so being cute, fancy or inspired doesn't cut it in most matches against nerd players.

Finally, there are a ton of FTP card games out there that have a much more involved system than this one.  Solforge was simply the dumbest easiest one I found and played it because I never played Pokemon or Yugi-oh and was wondering if I missed out on anything.  Apprently, not.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The great thing about early access is that sometimes games actually change for the better and Solforge is one of those rare games to do so.

Initally I had a bad run with the game which is pointless to talk about now since those issues are mostly gone now.

I really like the systems Solforge has in place, such as leveling up cards during the match which adds a 3rd layer to the game. A card might be bad now at Lv1 but during the match it might be better at Lv2 so do I play it now in order to level it up or do I stick to my better cards now?

Their is a lot I would have to explain about the game in order for this review to make sense and honestly even then it would sound confusing so you are better of trying this game out if you like card games.

Their is an active player pool still playing even after 2 years and the game is taking the usual cardgame routes in terms of playstyles but the in-match leveling system really sets Solforge apart from its competitors and that is probably why Solforge is still going strong.

Solforge is not for everyone, it is middle of the road as far as card games go but it is still young and the expansion packs have really shaken up the formula for how you play this game because originally it had some flaws to put it mildly whereas now it is a deep and engaging experience both creating and playing your deck.

As far as I am aware, ELO rating is not implemented yet which I am fine with because matches give no rewards. Win 3 games per day (even against AI, or oddly even from the AI fighting itself) and thats it for the day. No more and no less. The game does have a cash shop, its free to play so of course it does but outside of that everyone is pretty limited in how many cards they can farm a day and while that is okay it does also make playing feel kind of hollow at times because you may need a card to finish your planned deck and after your three wins of the day you are out of options.

Or you can pay, of course. Even if you do though their is no in-game ladder showing who is #1 etc and while that may be planned in the future if you are the kind to spend money on games like this be aware that you don't get any kind of trophy to show for your wins but on the flipside if you are not very good at card games then no one can see your low rank in this game so you are classed as equal amongst your peers which is a rare oddity in a competitive game.

Matches are too random though so the game is terrible in the face of its competition.

Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needs
http://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

reviewText:
Early Access Review

ORIGINALLY NOT EARLY ACCESS, SolForge is a decent free to play card game with some of the easiest mechanics of any card game I've ever played. Choose cards from four factions (nature, fire, death, and robots), make a 30 card deck, and fight the computer or an online opponent. You get two actions per turn (except for the first turn, when the player can only play one card), and as you play you gain levels in order to play higher-level cards. Any cards you don't play don't gain levels, and any cards you don't use get discarded.

Several cards synergize for higher levels of strategy, but overall this is a simple game anyone can play. If you don't mind being limited to only two actions per turn, that is.

solforge is a wonderful cross between magic and fantasy rpg. with it's unique deck bulding system, and vast library of expansions, you can make ANY deck you can think of to fit ANY play style. and best of all, you can play it as much as you want, as the core of the game revolves around actual deck battleing, not leveling up and energy/stamina managing.
the daily rewards are a nice bonus, and you can even earn powerful rares through drafting. and since solforge has been going for some odd years, they have done an excellent job balancing play and cards to give new players the opportunity to build good decks whilst still allowing long term players to expand their library with versatile strategy themes.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSolForge is an amazing game, and is the successor to Spectromancer by Dr. Richard Garfield.  I liked Spectromancer a lot, and the idea of making an original fantasy world with factions and lore, and adding leveling and deckbuilding mechanics to it brings about a phenomenal and innovative gaming experience.  However, I dislike that there is very little music, and the music that is there is very plain, and does not add to the SolForge experience.  This is a shame, as Spectromancer's soundtrack was one of the key elements of making it great.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I disagree that this game is pay to win, i have never paid for anything within this game and even after not playing for half a year and returning, I find that my old decks still hold up very well vs swarms of new cards I had never seen before including the ones that can go up to level 4.

*edit* After checking the shop for the first time in ages I've noticed they have bumped the price of free in game currency card packs by a ridiculous amount, which I suppose could make the game quite a bit more grindy when you are starting out, they have bumped the price from 900 silver to 5k which is ridiculous considering you normally get about 4-6k silver from your 3 wins bonus per day. This is clearly an attempt to make people purchase boosters with real money which is a shame.

That being said, what I like about this game is how the combat works, everything gets a lane and everything is required to attack, there is no saving a monster on the field for later nor in your hand as it gets refreshed every turn. This also prevents people from being total asses and just destroying all your monsters and leaving you alive forever like in other CCGs. When you use a card it levels up into the next tier and becomes unusuable until  you yourself level up, as the cards go through levels they get stat boosts and ability boosts, some of them even gain abilities they don't start with.

This IS a game you will have to play daily  if you want to have a decent deck though, you need 3 wins per day in order to get all the free rewards which include silver(free currency that can be used to buy basic boosters) and a random item that can be  an event ticket, a card(which is usually terrible and the worst reward) or a booster pack of any tier(I think I received 3 premium packs in the first month of playing). After about the first 2-3 weeks you should be able to assemble a decent deck and after that it's all a matter of tweaking. you are allowed to use cards from 2 out of the 4 factions in your deck which also creates some interesting combos.

Legendaries are well...legendaries, they either fall into the massive stats and terrible abilities type or the very  very squishy but amazing ability  type. Legendaries tend to start off way weaker at the first level but become better at endgame, what this means is that if you can put the pressure onto your enemy and  force them to put up normal monsters in order to defend, do it. This will cripple their lategame and potentially make the difference on whether you win or not.

Spells are also a major part of the game, there are no traps or secrets just regular spells. They can be buffs like armor, damage,  heals, special abilities like moving on the board or damage that goes through defending monsters etc. Or debuffs and damage: straight up nukes, poisons, debuffing of hp and attack(debuffing hp to negative CAN be used as a killing technique and has the benefit of going directly thorugh armor at the cost of usually doing way less damage than a nuke does).

It is a different system to get used to but once you do I find it is quite fun, matches are quite quick and you can play multiple at the same time, plus they just got android support so you can officially play it on just about any tablet or phone now. As long as you long in once a day and do your 3 wins (you can even play against bots if you're lazy since they're very easy) you will have very nice cards. The only cards you cannot get for free are the alternate arts*(essentially shiny cards) they release once a week

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I've spent a fair amount of time in SolForge. I love the art, music, lane-based combat, leveling cards based on what's used and drawing an entire new hand every turn, etc. But, as I've come to realize, the in-game currency is short of useless for anything other than painstakingly collecting tickets for tournaments.

See, Silver (earned) currency can only buy a handful of things. Decorative skins, new deck slots, tournament tickets, and the vanilla booster pack. This booster pack contains cards from all sets currently released. There are also the expansion booster packs, which require gold to purchase (via real cash). Every time a new set comes out, the Normal Booster has a lower and lower chance of getting specific cards. Sure, you could build those specific cards (after a month and a half has passed since release), but that requires tens of thousands of silver. Not to mention I noticed a dramatic drop in pulling rarity chances a while ago, probably in an attempts to push people into purchasing their 'legendary chests'.

Another game with great, unique mechanics flying the F2P banner, when really, they've been slowly making things more miserable for their players that can't afford to pay.

Early Access Review

5/10
I Felt the need to revise my review as the game seems to have gotten rid of most of the bugs and the netplay is actually usable. Having more cards, and a draft mode has made it better too..... almost gave a 6 and a recommend. Sadly the interface is still killing it. You still can't even tell what card the other player cast when they do spells, especially now there are more cards so it's alot harder to know. Seems the game still requires memorizing all cards. The new draft type I tried was also lacking (IE no way to view levels that was apparent)
Close, but no. Keep working on your game solforge and you might just get some more recommends (not just from me...)

Long and short is the interface actually works now, and now that it does I can see how crappy the interface really is..... It deserves going from a 4 to 5 just for the sheer miracle of improvement/bugs removed and the fact that they have some visible progress/effort. Now if they could just fix the interface I could make it a 6 and tell my friends its more fun than a headache now and try to play it again.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI know I havent played much but I am in love with this game already! reviewText:
Early Access Review

I recomend this as an alternative to hearthstone only if you have eye vision impairments. When starting out, you should do the tutorial.

However, in order to see your card's stats, you must click on cards. The problem with this garbage is you get a pop up menu that's GIGANTIC. You have to try to remember all the stats for the cards you want to check and then again for whatever to you want to play. So you live and die in pop-up's HELL / sub-menus. Not friendly for new people and the people who are not blind or are flat out too impatient to deal with this non-sense. Really made the game very difficult to get into. Infact, it pist me off so much I just removed it entirely. It's like those terrible mobile gaming apps with the million insultive adds. I can't stand this game mooning my face every time I need to see stats on something while being new. Due to this, I can't get into the game. I do not like having gaming obstruction when I'm trying to play any thing over lazy dev design. Not recommend for the IMPATIENT people. Having several large monitors I just couldn't get over at how clunky and poorly designed the UI is. Every thing is way too big. Are the DEVS BLIND PEOPLE? Are they coding the game with keyboard's that have braille? Is that why they can't see what their game looks like? WTF IS THIS MESS? The only dev that can doesn't have vission issue's is the art guy. If you click from main menu in chat, you just a long, strange, gross chat window for the game. It's just nasty. Blech! Gross, & more gross.

Why are we even paralle parking the damn cards like vehicles on the side of curbs on the road? We don't need it. You need to park a card to play just because you have so many cards. That's just eww & lazy. WTF FOR? Just let us slap down a card like in Hearthstone and so the stats on the cards or in a slide out menu or even just displaying the card when you click on it as a preview on the left side. Those DLC'S are just as expensive if not more as HearthStone. So for the price and the terrible vision displays, might as well play HearthStone. Unless if you are bored with HearthStone, then have at it. I don't see what's so attractive here or entertaining. WTF is up with the load screens? Taking turns seem's wonky in time as well and not quite balanced out properly. Passing on this one since it's for the blind with lot's of time to burn on turns. Turn's out people can have inappropriate names too that are highly offensive. Not the type of thing you want younger peeps to see.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI backed this on Kickstarter and have mostly moved to playing the iPad version now that it's available, but the game is the same on both systems. It's a free to play (not pay to win) collectible card game which takes advantage of being digital to incorporate a core mechanic which would technically be possible in analog but would be clunky and annoying at best. Cards level up and go back in the deck when played, making it so that the player must consider not only what cards can do now but what they can do later in the game when making plays. The game is 100% worth a try.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThe game is still glitchy, it fails to run on my computer and requires a reinstall every day or so, but the fact that I am willing to do that to play this game has to say something.  Its a unique CCG where you shuffle your discard pile back into your deck every 4 turns, and rank up your cards by doing so.  It makes it so you may play a crap card early just because later it get better, which in any other CCG you would avoid putting it in your deck to begin with.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

OVERALL: It's a fun quick CCG that has depth beneath the simple interface . But SolFoirge feels unfinished; like it's still in Beta. The lack of user trading really detracts from the deck building strengths within the game, and the expensive rare cards generally dictate the good decks. There isn't a ton of metagaming that can be done. It's a good game that needs about twice as many cards to allow for competitive play.

I'd play it in a year from now, assuming the above features get added, but I wouldn't recommend it to people at this moment.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

My favorite card game was Yu Gi Oh series, and it was great, but this game's nowhere near Yu Gi Oh. I had big expectation but came off disappointed.

Game's pretty lackluster, from repetitive background sound and seemingly too barebones battle mechanic. Graphic is ok though - like the art direction and animation.

Tutorial missions are there to help you, and they're good enough to introduce the mechanics in general. My own experience was quite good with the tutorials, but I had to replay them once each to understand better. Just me being bad here.

In game micro-transaction also ticks me off.

But hey, the game's free and it's still being developed. Hopefully they can polish this more to compete with the upcoming Heartstone by Blizzard.
