reviewText:
Early Access Review

It looks good but the gameplay is quite boring. Just outlast to level 3 units where you will actually duke things out.

PROS
1. Nice Visuals
The artwork for the cards are great.

2. Easy to Learn
Just play 2 cards every round if possible. Preferably choose units over spells as the stat point growth for units far exceed spells. E.g. Stone Giant 6/9 to 20/20 vs a 6 damage to 12 damage.

3. Interesting Abilities
Armour (Negates X damage on the first hit), Aggressive (Attack on Summon)

4. Campaign is okay
It's still another AI battle but it's campaign is better than some other online TCGs that I've played E.g. MMDOC (Google it)

CONS
1. Peculiar mechanic
The idea of a default mechanic where you gain a higher level card by playing a lower level card first is quite strange. E.g. Play a Level 1 card to gain a Level 2 card of the same card.

2. Repetitive cards
Card Levels go into 1, 2, 3. The next level is merely a buffed up version of the first card. E.g. Cull the Weak: Destroy any creature with 4/8/12 attack and below.

3. Pay-To-Win
You get normal booster packs with Silver (in-game currency) and rare booster packs with Gold (cash currency). People who spend cash on this game will get better cards than those who don't.

4. No Trading System
Can't see anyway to trade your cards so your cards are valueless.

5. Low Multiplayer Count
Hardly anyone playing.

6. Tournaments
Minimum number of event tickets to enter is 2. You need to pay cash to get these tickets. With such a low player count, I wonder why they even charge.

7. Bugs
Lot of bugs

8. No unique narrative
Standard undead horde, wild animals, technology city and primordial tribe cards. This is the same story as Infinity Wars. There is nothing unique.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

As a CCG, SolForge is one of the most solidly constructed games I've played in years. It takes full advantage of the fact that it exists in virtual space to explore mechanics that would be difficult or even impossible in real space. Also, instead of banning or restricting cards, if a card becomes unbalanced in play, they won't hesistate to update it to make it more functional. However, they don't go overboard changing cards all the time, either.

Like all the best games, it is fairly easy to learn, but hard to master. The basic concept is simple. You draw a hand of 5 cards, of which you can play two. There are spells and creatures. Creatures occupy one of 5 lanes. When you play a card, it levels up into another version of itself, usually a better version. How much better varies from card to card. Each turn you battle, any creature that doesn't have summoning sickness attacks the creature across from it, and if there is nothing across from it, it deals damage to the opposing player. At the end of your turn, you discard your entire hand, and draw 5 new cards. After four turns, you level up, meaning you reshuffle all your cards back into your deck, except now some of those cards are higher level. And this repeats, with your deck getting stronger as the game goes on.  There are four factions, and each of them plays differently. Decks are 30 cards, and can be made of one or two factions.

From that simple structure, there is a lot of depth in the game. This game was designed by Stoneblade Entertainment, the same company that created the Ascencion deckbuilding game, with the help of Richard Garfield (creator of Magic: The Gathering). Most of them are Magic protour veterans as well. The plan, for now, seems to be to release one major set and one minor update each year. There are timed and untimed matches, as well as tournaments and drafting. The game is built to be free to play, although it is still in beta, so many things like a single-player campaign and trading cards between players are not in yet, but the game is updated fairly regularly. I definitely recommend it to anyone who is keen on strategy games or CCGs, and the free to play nature makes it easy to try out.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I will start by saying that stoneblade has produced a card game with an innovative and very interesting core mechanic. However I have exhausted a considerable amount of time into the game and have come to the conclusion that RNG 'feels' like it plays too large a hand in the game.
Without going into specifics becuase people who are reading this may not have experienced the Solforge leveling system, I will say that more often than not you will lose matches and 'Feel' like you had absolutly no power. And unlike magic wereby matches you lose due to RNG are lost in the first few draws due to mana, Solforge matches are lost turn 20-30 around 10+ mintues into a match.
Basically an average game of solforge has you play a card you will need leveled later and then you cross your fingers in the hope that you draw that card when you need it. But more often than not you will never see that card again and if you do see it there may be no benefit in playing it.

In conclusion I don't mind losing when the game is close but the majoritiy of time you will lose because the level 1 creatures you draw will NEVER beat those level 3's your opponent keeps playing.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nSolForge is the only online CCG I have seen that makes good use of the online medium: most online CCGs could just as easily be done in cards, and most of them fall short of MtG; leaving me little reason to play them. SolForge, however, uses a leveling mechanism that could not be done in a paper CCG; and exploring the leveling system and the need to think not only what you want to play now; but also what you want leveled for later in the game, makes SolForge the one online CCG I am likely to keep playing.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

This game is kinda like playing a game of yatzee. far too random in its approach. at first it looked like a game i could really enjoy. i used to play a lot of magic and i saw a lot of similar elements. the problem lies in the rank system. you play a level 1 card and it ranks up to level 2 making it more powerful so as you go a few cards that you play get more powerful and the rest stay at lower levels. then you get to rank 3 and its entirely random as to getting a full hand of nearly worthless rank 1 stuff or getting an amazing hand or even set of hands with lots of high ranking stuff. this is pretty much determines who wins. many games i felt like i could have just tossed a coin in the air to decide the winner and that doesnt make it very fun. there are better cards you can accumulate as you play that give you more of an edge but i'm not really willing to spend the time or money to get there.
The draft system is also poorly imagined. you choose 30 cards for your deck but not from a pool of cards. first you pick one of 6 then one of 5 and 4 etc. frequently i wouldnt want any of the cards or just one but it wouldnt be the color that i want to play. there are 4 colors and you only get 2. there are amazing cards and i got a few on the first draft. i went 2 and 2. the second draft i played i felt like i got nothing useful and won 0 games. i recognize that sometimes you get a good hand and sometimes you dont but when it takes a week to get enough tickets to play draft i'm just not willing to waste the time needed.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While it may get a lot of flak, but overall its better than some other potential online CCGs. It has a bit of a learning curve to be noted. Your first win against an actual opponent each day gives you an event tickets, seven event tickets is a draft, a draft is effectively 6 packs. The game is about action economy, and there is a lot of potential optimization for it. Most legendaries aren't powerhouses innately, they're more of synnergy and improving deck archetypes. Extra copies of cards can be sold for silver, the non premium currency. Silver buys packs, individual cards (that you already own a copy of), backgrounds, and event tickets. If you need help or someone to trade wins with, join the steam chat by hitting the chat button in game.

Tl;Dr The game is about getting the most out of each card you play. Don't assume that the limits mean there is no skill or learning curve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not quite MTG, but fun and free! So, if you enjoy Mgic the Gathering type card games, here is a pretty polished early access game to try out.

The game is still very much in development, but one can already play against the AI or other players. Daily rewards help new players to get started with their card collection, and after about four months, I've got most cards (including heroic), and even some legendaries, just from the daily rewards. Tournament play was introduced just before christmas 2013, and offers additional chances for new cards, and another way to play against equal powered decks (draft tournament). Due to daily rewards, one can play maybe one draft tournament per week for free. Winning enough matches in them will provide additional tickets, allowing even more drafts without paying anything.

Online play tries to match players against roughly equal skills/cards, so the games should be relatively close ones. And remember, due to game mechanics, it is quite possible to win even after being 100-10 behind, so know and trust your cards and decks.

If you enjoy the game play, then there is a lot of fun to be had for free. If, on the other hand, you can't resist the urge to get all the legendaries, then prepare to pay. While legendaries have their place in decks, they are not required, and certainly do not guarantee a victory. Knowing the strengths and weaknesses of all cards is more valuable, so just playing with any deck against the AI will help you improve. Playing against other people allows you to see how cards you don't yet have might work, and allows for differing play styles from the AI.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome card game, nice detailed art. Matches don't last long because of the leveling system.This leveling system is pretty unique in that it does not in any way reflect a leveling card system outside of the matches. It is in fact you, the player, leveling up and the cards follow suit; which makes the match become faster when someone levels up.

Also, as a sidenote. There are three kinds of daily achievements in this stage of the game (early stages). these are 1 the daily login reward, 2 win a match (which is easy when you create match against easy ai) and 3 win three matches.

After those rewards, you're capable of buying a couple of small boosters.

So at this moment of the game, it's to play 15 min max a day.


EDIT  Ok, I've been playing the game for a while longer now and I have to say, my enthousiasm hasn't been depleted. One of the possible login rewards is the event cards which in the end (for example with 3 events cards) permit access to a tournament. The awesome thing is that, when you play that tournament and you lose all three matches, you still receive a normal booster (contains a lot more cards than small booster). If you win one out of three matches, you get your event cards back :o
(And I haven't even begon about drafting which, in the end,  gives you even more cards at your disposal (even after tournament).

With the adding of Iphone players, the playerbase has become larger which, in turn makes it faster to find an online opponent. AAAAnd if you win your first online match of the day, you receive another reward (this would be the fourth daily achievement). :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. It's strategic, challenging, and surprisingly visually interesting for what's essentially a cardgame. It definitely rewards long-term play and/or monetary investment, but it isn't PTW  and you scale quickly without any investment.

I also like how it would be impossible to play in the real world - that is to say, it makes good use of the fact that it's on a computer, rather than mimicing already extant cardgames like M:TG.

I would (and do!) recommend this one to friends.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nThis is the fast paced alternative to Magic the Gathering.  You don't have to wait around for land cards to come out before you can start playing cards, and the cards level up as you play which adds an element that I haven't seen before in this type of game.  Decks can only be two-toned, which means you can't put every card you like into a deck, but at the same time makes you experiment with a lot of deck combinations that you would probably ignore otherwise.  I've never bought a card myself, and my decks are pretty good, but if you want the best ones you'll probably have to fork over some cash.  If you like this type of game, you can't go wrong by giving it a try since it's free.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Awesome card game, nice detailed art. Matches don't last long because of the leveling system.This leveling system is pretty unique in that it does not in any way reflect a leveling card system outside of the matches. It is in fact you, the player, leveling up and the cards follow suit; which makes the match become faster when someone levels up.

Also, as a sidenote. There are three kinds of daily achievements in this stage of the game (early stages). these are 1 the daily login reward, 2 win a match (which is easy when you create match against easy ai) and 3 win three matches.

After those rewards, you're capable of buying a couple of small boosters.

So at this moment of the game, it's to play 15 min max a day.


EDIT  Ok, I've been playing the game for a while longer now and I have to say, my enthousiasm hasn't been depleted. One of the possible login rewards is the event cards which in the end (for example with 3 events cards) permit access to a tournament. The awesome thing is that, when you play that tournament and you lose all three matches, you still receive a normal booster (contains a lot more cards than small booster). If you win one out of three matches, you get your event cards back :o
(And I haven't even begon about drafting which, in the end,  gives you even more cards at your disposal (even after tournament).

With the adding of Iphone players, the playerbase has become larger which, in turn makes it faster to find an online opponent. AAAAnd if you win your first online match of the day, you receive another reward (this would be the fourth daily achievement). :D

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I love this game. It's strategic, challenging, and surprisingly visually interesting for what's essentially a cardgame. It definitely rewards long-term play and/or monetary investment, but it isn't PTW  and you scale quickly without any investment.

I also like how it would be impossible to play in the real world - that is to say, it makes good use of the fact that it's on a computer, rather than mimicing already extant cardgames like M:TG.

I would (and do!) recommend this one to friends.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

While it may get a lot of flak, but overall its better than some other potential online CCGs. It has a bit of a learning curve to be noted. Your first win against an actual opponent each day gives you an event tickets, seven event tickets is a draft, a draft is effectively 6 packs. The game is about action economy, and there is a lot of potential optimization for it. Most legendaries aren't powerhouses innately, they're more of synnergy and improving deck archetypes. Extra copies of cards can be sold for silver, the non premium currency. Silver buys packs, individual cards (that you already own a copy of), backgrounds, and event tickets. If you need help or someone to trade wins with, join the steam chat by hitting the chat button in game.

Tl;Dr The game is about getting the most out of each card you play. Don't assume that the limits mean there is no skill or learning curve.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

For anyone that has been following me on Youtube for the past few months, you probably noticed that my focus is on digital TCGs. And SolForge has been one of the most commonly played games. Currently I am sitting at over 150 hours played (though some of that may or may not have involved accidentally leaving the game on overnight a few times) and I have played countless hands. The style of this game is what I would call a lane game (as opposed to a MTG-like or a board game like game like Faeria).

First of all it is free to play. The game comes with 2 precon decks that are not in your card pool as far as I know (meaning that those 4 legendaries between the 2 decks you do not own). The prizes currently are fast to earn. Every day at midnight pacific time it resets. You get bonuses for loggin in, first win and 3rd win. The prizes are silver (free to play currency which can be used to buy play mats, the smallest booster pack, and deck slots), and randomized prizes which currently only includes cards or packs.

The pacing of this game is the most enjoyable I have ever played. It is easy to play a 5-10 minute hand and just as easy to lose yourself for hours at a time. The basic gameplay is so simple that I think my cat could learn it. But the strategy does present itself if you give the game a chance. Leveling up is the resource in this game and you need to play the right cards at the right time to progress your deck properly. There is still plenty of luck... but trust me. It is less than you think there is the first time you play a hand.

Plans for the future include: booster drafting and in game tournaments (coming in next patch that will be soon").
A new 20 card psuedo expansion which will be added to the current set. Save your silver to buy those new packs but don't be afraid to open any packs as old ones will not have new cards.
Graphical and UI upgrades.
And most importantly some form of trading and crafting.

If you are not in this game for the long haul now is the time to warn potential players. The pack system is currently very frustrating. You can only get the 3 card pack for free now. I recently opened 110 of these packs and only got 2 legendary cards. Premium packs guarantee 1 legendary card. But they cost $10. And there is no way to guarantee getting the legendary you want unless they are in one of the faction starter decks. Legendary cards aren't necessarily always better. But they add depth to decks and make certain strategies work better (or make SOME viable since they do not work without specific cards). Between the fact that there is CURRENTLY no trading or in game card crafting
date: it can be very frustrating for new players. Or even players like me. I Kickstarted this game. I used my store credit to buy 1 of each starter pack and 145 of the middle sized booster packs. And there are still numerous legendary cards that I have 0 copies of.\n\nThis game is good enough that I recommend it to anyone that loves lane based CCGs. But I want to say. If you are easily frustrated by RNG with packs. If MMDoC made you flip tables because of the lack of trading. I recommend just doing your daily bonuses against the AI
hoursPlayed: and waiting until trading is implemented in game. If you have the patience to slowly build a decent card pool
voteText: then go for it!  Otherwie just remember that beta is beta and SBE is still a small company. And there are plenty of CCGs out there right now while you wait for Kibler

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Not quite MTG, but fun and free! So, if you enjoy Mgic the Gathering type card games, here is a pretty polished early access game to try out.

The game is still very much in development, but one can already play against the AI or other players. Daily rewards help new players to get started with their card collection, and after about four months, I've got most cards (including heroic), and even some legendaries, just from the daily rewards. Tournament play was introduced just before christmas 2013, and offers additional chances for new cards, and another way to play against equal powered decks (draft tournament). Due to daily rewards, one can play maybe one draft tournament per week for free. Winning enough matches in them will provide additional tickets, allowing even more drafts without paying anything.

Online play tries to match players against roughly equal skills/cards, so the games should be relatively close ones. And remember, due to game mechanics, it is quite possible to win even after being 100-10 behind, so know and trust your cards and decks.

If you enjoy the game play, then there is a lot of fun to be had for free. If, on the other hand, you can't resist the urge to get all the legendaries, then prepare to pay. While legendaries have their place in decks, they are not required, and certainly do not guarantee a victory. Knowing the strengths and weaknesses of all cards is more valuable, so just playing with any deck against the AI will help you improve. Playing against other people allows you to see how cards you don't yet have might work, and allows for differing play styles from the AI.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It is a good game but still in a rough spot in terms of some aspects.  It is worth the small download, but it'll take you quite a long time before building a really competitive deck even if you pay in since every card and reward you get is random.  There is no trading yet or crafting, which is the real issue... but that is reportedly coming... eventually.

Also, if you do enjoy the gameplay, you'll find yourself required to log in every day to play 3 matches to collect all your daily rewards.  4 matches if you want to get every daily reward (the last one must be versus real players online but the first 3 can be earned from playing against the cpu).  It doesn't take a lot of time but it is required and a little bit of a menial repetitive task.  This can be a positive for some people and a negative to others.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: Wide card selection, easy to learn, and high skill ceiling.

Cons: It takes a LOOOOONG time to get anything done. You must double click on a card to view it's card text, but that takes several seconds to pop up and then some more time just to close it. Before you view a card's text, all you see is the art, power, and life. If it showed even a portion of the text box, then I'd be able to tell at a glance if the card is vanilla or not, but I can't. It also doesn't show you the faction (color) of the card without double clicking on it first - which is absurd. This MUST be sped up and changed into a mouse-over if the game is going to proceed at a reasonable speed.

Browsing through your card library is very slow. You can either view cards iOS app store style (1 at a time, swiping through hundreds of cards), or in a vertical list (very little information displayed). We need more view options that isn't as extreme as these 2 choices. Viewing card text is a single click, which is different from the main game. Double clicking adds a card to your deck. If you were just trying to read the card text, you'll then have go to a different menu (which is also slow) to remove the unintended card from your deck (and for some reason, the game allows you to add more than max deck size). This could be fixed if you could add cards with a different command, like right click.

In game timer is ridiculous. You have 20 minutes total to make all your moves, like speed jenga or speed chess. If that runs out, because either player is playing a defensive deck, then you have to start making moves faster. However, once that time gets down to around the 1 minute mark, you get an additional minute to make your moves, but that minute isn't added onto your total time. So if you had 1:05 left, at the beginning of your turn, you would have 2:05. Then if you finished with 1:10 left, your total time is now 0:10. Then for the rest of the game you have roughly 1 minute to make your moves, which is NOT enough with how SLOW it is to play and read cards. Just put a time limit on individual turns, like 180-200 seconds.

The font size in the game log (which is a text version of what moves each player made) is WAY too small. I'm talking like times new roman size 7 on windows. When I tried this on my android device, the text was indistinguishable from the dust and scratches on my screen protector. Probably font size 1.5 there. ALSO! The game log is hidden away in the menu, so it takes even MORE time to access. Since all spells aren't shown to the opponent as they are played (recycled animations are shown instead, so different spells may share the same animation), I have to rely on the game log to see what was played. The log MUST be more accessible and LEGIBLE if the game continues to animate the way it does now. I'm sure there are more problems with the game log, but I couldn't read any of the text. At the very least, I can make out the highlighted text to see the card that was played.

Great game with a bunch of potential. Fix these problems and I will gladly return.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nAlthough not quite as deep tactically as Magic: the Gathering, this is still a very fun card game that elegantly solves some typical CCG issues through its simplicity. You play two cards, all of your creatures that are in play attack every turn, and you discard your hand after each of your turns. I love the art direction, and the art is consistantly high-quality & interesting. As of this writing, the Campaign mode has yet to be implemented, and general functionality is somewhat barebones, but I'm looking forward to seeing the evolution of this game.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI have absolutely loved this game and it is a shame it is not more popular than it is. I have played this game more than any other game on steam, and besides the $20 I spent to buy the game before it went F2P, I have not spent any money on it. Solforge loses complexity by only, generally, having the option to play two out of the random five cards you draw each turn. However, it makes up for this lack of strategy by forcing the player to not just play whatever card is most optimal in the given situation, but also consider what cards you are leveling up and how this will impact your late game (a card levels up" into a new version of that card whenever you play it which makes it more powerful by increasing health
recommended: and sometimes granting or changing abilities. Generally a card has three ranks and your hero levels up every 4 turns allowing you to play cards of the next rank and all previous ranks). I absolutely love this element of strategy that

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros:

Nice big colourful battlefield where you don't have to strain your eyes reading tiny text

No mana dependence

Easy earning of ingame currency with daily logins and 3 wins

You can buy any card with your earned currency (though getting a legendary can take up to 15 days of play)

Interesting and complex card interactions

Cons:
Newbie decks are often matched up with legendary filled decks - this is probably one of the biggest reasons why new players will get discouraged and not stay with Solforge - a newbie would rather wait to be matched up with another newbie than be matched up fast with a super deck

You can only play 2 cards per turn usually, which feels too limiting and drives players inevitably towards the cards which help break that rule - 3 would provide better balance and create even more interesting interactions. Seriously only being able to play 2 cards per turn is a major drag lol. It almost makes me want the mana/resources system back so that I can get to play more than 2 cards

Screen layout and decor still feels a bit stiff and amateurish

Most of the strong decks all pack in Nekrium ('black') legendary cards - that is so obvious an imbalance that needs to be addressed and I'm very surprised they haven't yet - are they Satanic programmers or something hehe

Conclusion:

If you're a newbie, play it daily for just three wins (can be against computer) until you strengthen your card collection and you won't get frustrated. Remember you can forge any card you want with the silver you earn ingame.

The game has great potential, perhaps as much as Magic The Gathering when it first started out, and with new cards introduced regularly and speedily to compete with other card games, especially non-Nekrium legendaries, the game will be more colorful, balanced, varied and interesting. Those are imho the only ways it can genuinely catch up with MTG.

reviewText: Early Access Review\n\nI most definetly suggest this game for anyone that is into CCGs.  You may read alot of reviews nagging about the P2W, but what card game isn't.  If you are into MTG, Pokemon, Yugi, or any other CCG then I am sure that you have dropped more money then you would like to think about. Think about it for a momment.  A booster of MTG will cost you $3-$5 depending on the set which will get you 15 cards. Same goes for any CCG. Then there are the single cards that can go for way more than what a booster or even a box will cost you.  If you are a serious CCG player then you know what I am talking about. I didn't start paying for things until I had played for a few months.  I figured that the game had provided me with plenty of entertainment that sending a few bucks here and there wasn't a bad idea.  As for this grind people speak about it really isn't that bad.  During your dailies you can get up to 3 free boosters and enough silver to buy 2 more and boosters are worth 5000 silver which will get you 6 cards.  I have also recieved legendary chests as a daily reward as well.  I have collected a majority of my legendaries this way. Yes, I have bought a few of the precon decks, but thats like buying a precon deck with any CCG.   So I do not see the big gripe with the P2W asspect when it is the same for all CCGs.  The other complaint I see a lot is that you need legendaries to win and I call BS on this.  I played for the longest time without legendaries and I would still win online matches against people with stacks of legendaries.  Do legendaries help? Yes, they can. So can mythic rares and rares in MTG but they don't always make the deck. Its all about synergy and knowing how to make a proper deck.  When I played MTG those were my favorite decks to win with.  Playing against people that have dropped hundreds of dollars on their deck where mine would be but a fraction of what they spent.  One of my MTG decks that has yet to lose consists of nothing but commons and uncommons.  I took this tactic over to Solforge and it still works time to time. Like in any game you are going to win some and lose a lot.  You have to keep analysing whats out there and try to think of something that no one else has and surprise people.  If you are into CCG then I say give it a try cause as a person with 18 years of CCG playing I say it is worth it.

I'm an avid Magic: the Gathering player and all-around CCG player. With that said, I think SolForge is one of the best and quickest paced card games I've played in the 18+ years I've been playing card games. I would definitely recommend this game to any and all CCG fans that I know.
The best thing about the game truly has to be the leveling and ranking. This is something that I haven't seen in any other CCG before and greatly enjoy.
The worst part about this game is that after most all update (especially when new sets come out) there is always a long list of bugs that come with. Most players will experience anything from not being able to create/update decks all the way to failing to load the game at all.
Overall this is a great game that I think most players familiar to CCG's would love and could easily devoted many hours to like I have.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is playable and reasonably entertaining from a basic playability standpoint; but deck building is an exercise in needless frustration and there are massive issues with competitive online play that doom SolForge to meet an early grave. I won't waste time describing the same issues others already have:
Timed and untimed matches encourage abuse. Trolls either wait until the clock is about to run out before they play, or they leave untimed matches sitting there until the opponent concedes to get rid of it.
A single mediocre draw basically ends your game because there's no way to catch up once you're behind
The interface has obnoxious inconsistencies (i.e. Double-click does very different things in differet screens)
Very laggy performance, especially in the deck builder
Many other issues...
Instead, I'm going to focus on a single point that has grown to end any chance of the game being playable for any incoming player. At this stage, there's no realistic way to compete with players that have been around for months because their decks are loaded with the rarist cards in the game (legendary and heroic). Catching up at this stage would require an investment of several hundred, or even thousands of dollars.

I've played dozens of people, to the point that I see certain names often enough that I know their decks and what to expect; and every card in their deck is wildly more powerful than almost every card I've been able to get in more than a month of play. At this point, I'm pretty sure the only people still active in the game are long-term players. The few new players come in briefly, see how much of a mess it is, and promptly leave.

It's a complete waste of time to invest in this game, even if the balance issues are worked out, the cheating/trolling is curtailed, and more players join. Save yourself the hassle and find something else to do with your time.

Seriously only being able to play 2 cards per turn is a major drag lol. It almost makes me want the mana/resources system back so that I can get to play more than 2 cards

Screen layout and decor still feels a bit stiff and amateurish

Most of the strong decks all pack in Nekrium ('black') legendary cards - that is so obvious an imbalance that needs to be addressed and I'm very surprised they haven't yet - are they Satanic programmers or something hehe

Conclusion:

If you're a newbie, play it daily for just three wins (can be against computer) until you strengthen your card collection and you won't get frustrated. Remember you can forge any card you want with the silver you earn ingame.

The game has great potential, perhaps as much as Magic The Gathering when it first started out, and with new cards introduced regularly and speedily to compete with other card games, especially non-Nekrium legendaries, the game will be more colorful, balanced, varied and interesting. Those are imho the only ways it can genuinely catch up with MTG.

The worst part about this game is that after most all update (especially when new sets come out) there is always a long list of bugs that come with. Most players will experience anything from not being able to create/update decks all the way to failing to load the game at all.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

The game is playable and reasonably entertaining from a basic playability standpoint; but deck building is an exercise in needless frustration and there are massive issues with competitive online play that doom SolForge to meet an early grave. I won't waste time describing the same issues others already have:
Timed and untimed matches encourage abuse. Trolls either wait until the clock is about to run out before they play, or they leave untimed matches sitting there until the opponent concedes to get rid of it.
A single mediocre draw basically ends your game because there's no way to catch up once you're behind
The interface has obnoxious inconsistencies (i.e. Double-click does very different things in differet screens)
Very laggy performance, especially in the deck builder
Many other issues...
Instead, I'm going to focus on a single point that has grown to end any chance of the game being playable for any incoming player. At this stage, there's no realistic way to compete with players that have been around for months because their decks are loaded with the rarist cards in the game (legendary and heroic). Catching up at this stage would require an investment of several hundred, or even thousands of dollars.

I've played dozens of people, to the point that I see certain names often enough that I know their decks and what to expect; and every card in their deck is wildly more powerful than almost every card I've been able to get in more than a month of play. At this point, I'm pretty sure the only people still active in the game are long-term players. The few new players come in briefly, see how much of a mess it is, and promptly leave.

It's a complete waste of time to invest in this game, even if the balance issues are worked out, the cheating/trolling is curtailed, and more players join. Save yourself the hassle and find something else to do with your time.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Solforge is a free to play online collectible card game, made by Stoneblade Entertainment who are essentially a super team of Magic the Gathering veterans who joined up with the godfather of tcgs Richard Garfield to make this product.
Solforge is perfect for anyone who loves to play tcgs, but hasn't the time or money to do that anymore, the rules are simple, but the longer you play it the more you will discover the deep strategies this game inherents. The simple ruleset also makes this game great for tcg starters who can grasp the rules very quickly.
Basically there are 5 lanes and each turn you may play two cards are turn, creatures attack every turn (even in the opponents) and will battle either creatures on the opposing lane or hit the opponent directly. Both players have 100 lifes and your goal is to bring your opponent to 0. Now here comes the clue of the game: There is no resource system like Magic's mana system you just play two cards every turn, but every card has three different levels and cards level as they get played, coming back much stronger later in the game. So you have cards which are good on lvl 1 but might not be good to play because they level badly and there are other cards who do next to nothing on level 1 but might be gigantic later on. The leveling makes for interesting decisions, because you always have to consider if you can allow to level a stronger card or if you want to get ahead on board.
If you want to play the game for free you can easily do it, Solforge has a front loaded reward system where you don't need to grind for hours to get your stuff. And you can even draft which is a ton of fun and allows to get many new cards.
Since Solforge is currently in open beta there are more features to come: A crafting system, set 2 and a single player campaign are all down the line. The game is also available for Iphone and Ipad and will support Android devices on one point.
I would recommend this game for anyone who loves tcgs, because this is in my honest opinion the best one you can play on your computer (except maybe magic online, but it is a pain to play with it and is ridiculous expensive) but also for anyone else who is interested in this genre, this game is a good starting point for it.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

Pros: Wide card selection, easy to learn, and high skill ceiling.

Cons: It takes a LOOOOONG time to get anything done. You must double click on a card to view it's card text, but that takes several seconds to pop up and then some more time just to close it. Before you view a card's text, all you see is the art, power, and life. If it showed even a portion of the text box, then I'd be able to tell at a glance if the card is vanilla or not, but I can't. It also doesn't show you the faction (color) of the card without double clicking on it first - which is absurd. This MUST be sped up and changed into a mouse-over if the game is going to proceed at a reasonable speed.

Browsing through your card library is very slow. You can either view cards iOS app store style (1 at a time, swiping through hundreds of cards), or in a vertical list (very little information displayed). We need more view options that isn't as extreme as these 2 choices. Viewing card text is a single click, which is different from the main game. Double clicking adds a card to your deck. If you were just trying to read the card text, you'll then have go to a different menu (which is also slow) to remove the unintended card from your deck (and for some reason, the game allows you to add more than max deck size). This could be fixed if you could add cards with a different command, like right click.

In game timer is ridiculous. You have 20 minutes total to make all your moves, like speed jenga or speed chess. If that runs out, because either player is playing a defensive deck, then you have to start making moves faster. However, once that time gets down to around the 1 minute mark, you get an additional minute to make your moves, but that minute isn't added onto your total time. So if you had 1:05 left, at the beginning of your turn, you would have 2:05. Then if you finished with 1:10 left, your total time is now 0:10. Then for the rest of the game you have roughly 1 minute to make your moves, which is NOT enough with how SLOW it is to play and read cards. Just put a time limit on individual turns, like 180-200 seconds.

The font size in the game log (which is a text version of what moves each player made) is WAY too small. I'm talking like times new roman size 7 on windows. When I tried this on my android device, the text was indistinguishable from the dust and scratches on my screen protector. Probably font size 1.5 there. ALSO! The game log is hidden away in the menu, so it takes even MORE time to access. Since all spells aren't shown to the opponent as they are played (recycled animations are shown instead, so different spells may share the same animation), I have to rely on the game log to see what was played. The log MUST be more accessible and LEGIBLE if the game continues to animate the way it does now. I'm sure there are more problems with the game log, but I couldn't read any of the text. At the very least, I can make out the highlighted text to see the card that was played.

Great game with a bunch of potential. Fix these problems and I will gladly return.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

I have been playing this game for a while now(mostly on phone) and so far it's pretty enjoyable even as a free to play. You can make some decent decks with only common and rare cards and get decent daily rewards. There is one thing that really bothers me and I think most f2p players in this game. There is no ranked system to seperate from normal online matches. Why does this bother me? 9 out of 10 players I face in a normal online match have insane full heroic/legendary decks while I only have some heroics and a few legendaries(which I can not make a decent deck from). I maybe win about 2 out of 5 games I play online but for f2p or new players it is really hard to get started.

But besides that it can be pretty satisfying winning a game against players with a full heroic/legendary deck with only common and rare cards. There is a really big cardpool to make and try a lot of different decks and a lot of different and unique card effects.

I can't say anything about the tournaments because I never did one of those(might try those later).

The UI is pretty bad but it doesn't bother me that much but please Stone Blade, make a ranked system so newer players can get some fair opponents in online mathes.

I will give this a 7/10(this could've been an 8/10 if there was a fair matchmaking for online matches). I do recommend trying this out even if it is hard to get started. If you like TCG's with lots of variaty in cards, lots of deckbuilding and tweaking, this can be an interesting game for you.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

After playing SolForge for a while, I can say that it's no Magic: The Gathering, but it isn't bad. You get one booster pack per day just for logging in, you can earn more by winning games, and there's a single-player campaign mode that - while fairly thin - still provides a good tutorial first and a rather crushing bit of challenge later on.

Will you run up against truly unfair decks online? Oh, hells yes. Will you eventually make crushingly unfair decks of your own? Sure. All in all, it's not a bad F2P - and I define that as A F2P that you really don't have to spend money to enjoy."

PROS:
-Interesting gameplay.
-No need to spend money
date:
though earning cards through winning will take time.
-Single-player mode intact.
-Also available on Android

CONS:
-Some minor balance issues
recommended:
although some of the most broken cards have been taken care of over time.
-Repetitive music.
-Getting your first competitive deck together will certainly take a while.

Overall: 7/10. One of the better card games available on Steam."

reviewText:
Early Access Review

EDIT : 7 out of 10 people thought the game needed a new client and was getting stale...
but still recommendable

I am rewriting this review because of the new Client coming out. They have fixed the insane long times, fixed the buggyness except for the current temporary server issue.

I can understand that as a tradeoff they would remove the ability to use the free silver to make specific cards, even if its a lot of silver. And force us to use the golden chest with a guaranteed chance at a random legendary..

BUT NO MORE GOLDEN CHESTS = You cannot save a lot of silver for playing a lot of regular games to at least have a guarantee of having SOMETHING valuable...

Maybe some competitive players and whatnot will enjoy the new ranked ladder and the cleaned up content. But Solforges MAIN DRAW is - as of the time of writing this review - gone and the game took a firm step towards P2P.

New players beware.
